Problem:
Consider a system of linear equations given by \\(Ax = b\\), where A is a matrix and b is a vector. We investigate the influence of a transformation \\(f(x) = Mx + c\\), where M is another matrix and c is a constant vector, on the solution x.

If the transformation \\(f(x)\\) is applied to a solution vector \\(x_0\\), and then this transformed vector is used to solve \\(Ax = b\\) without further intervention, will the resulting vector \\(x(T)\\) match the original \\(x_0\\) used if no transformation had been applied?
Explanation: Applying the transformation \\(f(x) = Mx + c\\) alters the initial vector, changing the equation to \\(A(Mx + c) = b\\). Unless M is the identity matrix and c is the zero vector, the solution vector \\(x(T)\\) will generally be different from the original \\(x_0\\) due to the modification of the system.

causal_map_integration: Applying the transformation f(x) to x_0 results in x(T), and since A is the same for both x_0 and x(T), x(T) will match x_0 only if M is the identity matrix and c is the zero vector.
